item.title: Ticket #3039 (<?php wp_link_pages(); ?> related bug in all versions of WP) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
RuddO,

I considered that, but it's too late at that point to do a 301... headers already sent.

Also, this vulnerability already exists in that you can specify multiple URLs for a post that'll lead to the same content, but have a different URL.

item.title: Ticket #3039 (<?php wp_link_pages(); ?> related bug in all versions of WP) reopened
item.dc:creator: RuddO

item.title: Ticket #3039 (<?php wp_link_pages(); ?> related bug in all versions of WP) updated
item.dc:creator: RuddO
item.description: The patch should issue a 301 permanent redirect to the highest page number, otherwise a malicious person could exploit this by creating a page in their web host that points to a post in your blog, adding /1, /2 /.... 1000. Then google would get angry at your blog and say "tons of duplicate content" in SERPs.

item.title: patch.txt attached to Ticket #3065

item.description: This is my first ever wordpress core patch submission! It aims to fix a problem I had with ampersands when syndicating feeds.

item.title: Ticket #3065 (Ampersand in URL patch (needed as rss validation failed in a ...) created
item.dc:creator: murky
item.description:
I have a wordpress installation where I was drawing feeds in from elsewhere, sme of these feeds had & in the wrong places (e.g. urls) and this gave me validation issues.

After much wailing and gnashing of teeth, I patched it. Now, the current trunk is different from my installation, feed-functions.php has been moved into feeds.php for instance, so this patch is slightly different to my installation. I hope that this won't cause an unforeseen problem!

item.title: Ticket #3064 (Ampersand Patch) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
SVN Commit access is closed... two people commit patches: Matt and Ryan.

The process is as follows:

  • svn co ​http://automattic.com/wordpress/trunk/ .
  • change the code
  • svn di > patch001.diff
  • Create a new ticket in Trac. ​http://trac.wordpress.org/newticket
  • Upload the patch to the newly created ticket
  • Monitor the ticket for responses... revise patch as needed
  • Someone like me may recommend the patch for commit
  • Matt/Ryan commits the patch, if it's acceptable

Don't mark tickets with patches as resolved... add the keyword "has-patch" When Matt/Ryan commits the patch, THEN they'll mark it as resolved. We don't consider the issue resolved until the core code has been patched.

So, why don't you create a new ticket for this issue and upload your patch. thanks for contributing!

item.title: Ticket #3064 (Ampersand Patch) reopened
item.dc:creator: murky
item.description:
svn commit did not work (my username/password not accepted... reasonable as you don't need anyone able to commit changes!)

I've attached my patch here (though I couldn't find function comments_link in the current trunk, time is short, so I've only patched two of the three)

Hope I've done this right!

fixed:

Patches to be submitted soon.

I'll keep hunting for details of how to submit a patch for a little while.

item.title: Ticket #3063 (Blogger Import failing with Blogger Beta) created
item.dc:creator: benn333
item.description: Goolge has moved to Google logins with the new Blogger beta. Unfortunately, if someone has upgraded their Blogger account and attempts to import their blog into WordPress they are unable to log in. (It has also been ​reported here.) The message is "Login failed. Please re-enter your username and password." I have tested this on both my fresh install on my own server and my current free WordPress account with the same result. Can anyone help update this script? I have a bit of PHP experience, and am willing to contribute what I can.

No, not true. I just wrote a plugin that does some sort of thing like you say here. You should use the posts_where hook.

WP devs: am I right?

item.title: Ticket #3062 (the_posts filtering should be done earlier) updated
item.dc:creator: coppit
item.description: Also, the count for monthly archives should be computed after the_posts filtering, so that if I happen to filter out all the posts, the count should be 0, not the unfiltered count.

item.title: Ticket #3062 (the_posts filtering should be done earlier) created
item.dc:creator: coppit
item.description:
the_posts can be used to remove posts from the blog. However, it is called *after* the posts for a page are computed. This means that if I happen to filter out all of the posts for a page, posts from the next page will not slide up, leaving me with a blank page and a "next page" link.

Posts should be filtered with the_posts, then the results should be split into pages.

item.title: Ticket #3061 (Visual Rich Editor regularly crashing Firefox 1.5.0.6) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Keywords changed

Is this vanilla 1.5.0.6 or one with extensions installed?

If you have extensions installed which ones?

Does it work reliably with all you extentions disabled?

item.title: Ticket #3061 (Visual Rich Editor regularly crashing Firefox 1.5.0.6) created
item.dc:creator: circuit
item.description:
I was using the Rich Editor with no problems before upgrading to Firefox 1.5.0.6 (Win). I now get regular crashes, pretty much every time I use the editor.

Viewing the source as HTML causes a crash, and inserting uploaded images can occasionally cause a crash.

I have noted that highlighting a word, clicking the 'URI' button and entering a link is a common culprit of the crash. It often happens after creating three or four links - the next one will crash the whole browser. However, it can happen first time as well.

This happens on all my installations of Wordpress (five in total).

I have not found 1.5.0.6 to be particularly stable on my machine generally, but the Rich Editor is notoriously bad, so much so that I am now forced to turn it off.

item.title: 569.diff attached to Ticket #569
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: urlencode pathinfo before we try to match it in parse_request()

item.title: Ticket #569 (Percent sign (%) in title leads to unusable permalinks) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description:
Keywords, Version, Milestone changed

I believe I've found the problem. In parse_request() in classes.php, the path info is stripped from the end of the requested URI. However, the path is not URI encoded, so it fails to match in the str_replace. This patch urlencodes the path info (minus slashes) so it can be tested properly.

With the patch applied, all permalinks, including encoded ones, are followable.

item.title: Ticket #3052 (pingback_ping() function displays wrong content in pingback-display in ...) updated
item.dc:creator: webrocker
item.description:
ok, actually I have to deal with 2 different "bugs". the first is kind-of template related:
1) with the original xmlrpc.php, page-navigation- and meta-link-contents will show up as excerpt in the pingback, if they are wrapped inside <div></div> tags and not <p></p> tags. This can be fixed by adding div to the regex in line 1192 of the pingback_ping() function as stated above.

the second is caused by the use of the ultimate tag warrior plugin:
2) if it is used to display "related posts", and the pinging post has the same tags as the pinged post, the link to the pinged post will appear inside this "related posts" navigation - and the first appearance of that link will trigger the "excerpt" of the pingback. since the "related posts" navigation can appear anywhere inside the page, depending on the template, there is no way to tell which instance of the link is the "correct" one to use for the pingback excerpt. :-(
2) will only happen with pingbacks inside the same blog, 1) happens to "foreign" pingbacks as well, so I think 1) should be treated as a bug and 2)... hm, well, dunno.

item.title: Ticket #3052 (pingback_ping() function displays wrong content in pingback-display in ...) updated
item.dc:creator: webrocker
item.description:
Keywords changed

hm. the problem re-occured in my blog today, despite my "fix". I use permalinks with "pathinfo", i.e.
http:/mydomain.tld/myblog/index.php/2006/08/12/my-title/
A post with a nearly identical title ("brave new internet revisited") to the pinged post ("brave new internet") produced a pingback with again the wrong contents in it; again the "related posts" navigation showed up as the excerpt in the pingback display.

item.title: Ticket #3060 (Massive Code Cleanup: wp-includes/bookmark-template.php) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Massive Code Cleanup returns, with a focus on bookmark-template.php

  • Spaces to tabs, tabs to spaces, where appropriate
  • Kill trailing tabs and spaces
  • Unnecessary braces and parenthesis eliminated
  • Proper indentation
  • if ( 'something' == $var )
  • foreach ( (array) $foo as $bar )
  • strstr() to strpos() (speed benefit)
  • Leaner return/echo blocks
